  "article_text": [
    "consider a complex geodesic for the teichmller metric @xmath5 from the upper half plane to teichmller space .",
    "these geodesics are generated by a pair @xmath6 of a riemann surface @xmath7 of genus @xmath8 and a quadratic differential @xmath9 .",
    "the ( rare ) examples where the stabilizer in the mapping class group of @xmath10 is a lattice @xmath11 are called _",
    "teichmller curves_.    a particular case of these geodesics with lattice stabilizer can be described as follows : take an assemblage of squares of paper and glue them along their edges to a surface without boundary , such that at each vertex abut an even number of squares .",
    "if we provide the squares with a complex structure and glue the local quadratic differentials @xmath12 , we obtain a pair @xmath6 .",
    "this description lead lochak ( @xcite ) to baptise them _",
    "origamis_. if the glueing is just by translations ( and not by @xmath13 composed by a translation ) the origami is said to be _",
    "oriented_. oriented origamis are also known as square - tiled coverings or non - primitive teichmller curves .",
    "lochak remarked that the corresponding _ origami curves _",
    "@xmath14 in the moduli space of curves are defined over number fields and hence interesting not only in dynamical systems but also from a number theoretical viewpoint .",
    "we study two examples ( section [ exams ] ) of origamis : the smallest example ( called @xmath15 ) where @xmath7 has genus greater than one and the smallest example ( called @xmath16 ) with a property relevant for the @xmath17-comparisons , see below . in both cases",
    "we explicitly write down the equation of the origami curve in moduli space .",
    "this possibility seems rather unexpected from the geodesic viewpoint .",
    "the above definition suggests that  in the oriented case  origami curves are in fact ( the analytic version of ) some hurwitz spaces for coverings of elliptic curves , ramified at most over @xmath18 .",
    "it is very natural to consider the geodesic discs then in @xmath19}$ ] with the @xmath20 preimages of @xmath18 marked but unordered .",
    "the hurwitz viewpoint reproves that origami curves and the map @xmath21 are defined over number fields .",
    "it implies that there is an action of the absolute galois group @xmath2 on the set of origami curves .",
    "our first main result is that this action is faithful in the following sense ( we abbreviate @xmath22 by @xmath23 throughout ) :    * theorem [ faithfulthm ] * _ for each @xmath24 there is an origami curve @xmath0 isomorphic to @xmath23 , such that @xmath25 acts non - trivially on the map @xmath26}$ ] , more precisely such that @xmath27 .",
    "_    there are examples of origami curves , that do not have genus @xmath28 .",
    "( @xcite ) .",
    "it would be interesting to know , if the @xmath2-action is faithful on the ( abstract , not embedded ) origami curves .",
    "let us give an overview over grothendieck - teichmller theory .",
    "the technical details will be explained in section [ ongt ] .",
    "the absolute galois group @xmath2 acts on the algebraic fundamental group @xmath29 , which is isomorphic to the profinite free group @xmath30 in two generators .",
    "this action can be described in terms of pairs @xmath31 with a suitable composition law .",
    "the subgroup of pairs satisfying three equations ( due to drinfeld ) is the grothendieck - teichmller group @xmath17 . by construction",
    "it contains @xmath2 and the question is whether it is strictly larger than @xmath2 or not .",
    "one hence would like to find a set of equations that singles out precisely @xmath2 .",
    "where should these relations come from ?",
    "consider a category @xmath32 of varieties ( or stacks ) over @xmath33 with some morphisms defined over @xmath33 .",
    "for a large enough @xmath32 only @xmath2 acts equivariantly on all @xmath34 by a result of f. pop .",
    "but only for a few types of geometric morphisms one is able to express the equivariance in terms of @xmath35 . among these",
    "are some coverings of curves ( @xcite , @xcite ) , and natural morphisms between moduli spaces of curves ( @xcite , @xcite , @xcite ) .",
    "maps from curves to moduli spaces should be considered next .",
    "the map of some origami curves to moduli space are defined over @xmath33 and geometric in this sense .",
    "we need that the curve @xmath36 and that it passes through a maximally degenerate point of the ( compactified ) moduli space .",
    "the smallest such origami is the @xmath16 .",
    "let @xmath37 denote the standard generators ( see section [ compgalact ] ) of the profinite mapping class group @xmath38 . for @xmath39",
    "such that the kummer cocycle @xmath40 we obtain the following relation :    * theorem [ newgtrel]  * _ the element @xmath41 respects the galois actions on the morphism @xmath42 induced from the two - steps origami @xmath16 ( see figure @xmath43 ) if and only if @xmath44 holds in @xmath38 .",
    "the elements @xmath45 satisfying this relation form a subgroup of @xmath17 containing @xmath2 .",
    "_    in section [ compgalact ] we prove the refined relation for all @xmath2 . as for all the relations in @xmath17",
    "recently discovered it is not known , if the subgroup defined by this relation is properly between @xmath2 and @xmath17 .",
    "the author thanks pierre lochak and leila schneps a lot for introducing him to this subject and a lot of support .",
    "he also thanks w.  herfort and h.  nakamura for their suggestions .",
    "a holomorphic quadratic differential @xmath46 on a riemann surface @xmath7 of genus @xmath8 determines on @xmath7 minus the set of zeroes of @xmath9 an atlas of open charts , whose transition functions are of the form @xmath47 .",
    "such an atlas is called a _ flat structure _ on @xmath7 . conversely a flat structure determines a quadratic differential by glueing the local @xmath12 s .",
    "this correspondence is given in more details in @xcite ch .",
    "2 . 15:58 there is a natural @xmath48 action on pairs @xmath6 by postcomposing the charts of the flat structure with the linear map .",
    "the stabilizer of a pair @xmath6 is precisely @xmath49 .",
    "we define the _ teichmller space _ @xmath50 as the space of riemann surfaces plus an isotopy class of orientation - preserving diffeomorphism ( a _ teichmller marking _ ) to a reference surface @xmath51 .",
    "if we choose a teichmller marking on @xmath7 , the action @xmath52 yields a geodesic curve ( by teichmller s theorems ) @xmath53 .",
    "we denote by @xmath54 the moduli stack of curves and the corresponding coarse moduli space by non - calligraphic letters , i.e.  @xmath1 .",
    "consider the projection of a geodesic @xmath55 to @xmath56 .",
    "we consider the moduli space in the first two sections in the analytic category .",
    "more precisely we should write @xmath57 , etc .",
    "let @xmath58 be the mapping class group of riemann surfaces of genus @xmath8 with @xmath20 punctures .",
    "we define @xmath59 to be the ( setwise ) stabilizer of @xmath60 and @xmath61 to be the pointwise stabilizer .",
    "we summarize this by an exact sequence @xmath62 & { { \\rm aut}}(\\tilde{\\j } ) \\ar[r ] & { { \\rm stab}}(\\tilde{\\j } ) \\ar[r ] &   { \\overline}{{{\\rm stab}}(\\tilde{\\j } ) } \\ar[r ] & 1 . } \\ ] ] the map @xmath10 descends to a map @xmath63    this map @xmath21 is called a _ teichmller curve _ if  @xmath64 is a lattice in @xmath65 .",
    "later on it will sometimes be natural to fix say @xmath20 marked points , consider @xmath66 and consider the stabilizer in @xmath58 ( or in @xmath67}$ ] , if we allow permutation of the marked points ) .",
    "we then call the groups @xmath68 ( or @xmath69)$ ] ) etc",
    ".    we can also describe this group using the flat structure defined by @xmath6 .",
    "denote by @xmath70 the group of orientation preserving affine diffeomorphisms of @xmath7 , i.e.diffeomorphisms which are affine with respect to the charts of the flat structure determined by @xmath9 .",
    "associating with @xmath71 the matrix part of the affine maps yields a well - defined map @xmath72 to @xmath73 .",
    "we denote the image of @xmath72 by @xmath74 .",
    "we obtain an exact sequence @xmath62 & { { \\rm aut}}(x , q ) \\ar[r ] & { { \\rm aff}}^+(x , q ) \\ar[r]^d &   psl(x , q ) \\ar[r ] & 1,}\\ ] ] where @xmath75 are the ( conformal ) automorphisms of @xmath7 preserving @xmath9 .",

    "affine diffeomorphisms in @xmath77)$ ] are called _",
    "balanced_.    \\i ) the groups @xmath64 and @xmath74 are closely related , namely ( see @xcite prop .",
    "3.2 ) if we identify @xmath65 with @xmath73 , we have @xmath80",
    "the same holds for the corresponding groups with marked points .",
    "ii ) while @xmath64 is best suited for moduli problems , we will use the definition of @xmath74 for calculations of these groups , because affine diffeomorphisms are easily visualized .",
    "we consider now a special case of teichmller curves :    an origami is a finite set of squares ( say unit squares in @xmath81 ) glued together along their edges to a surface without boundary , such that at each vertex abut an even number of squares",
    ".    using also open charts covering the glueing edges and identifying @xmath81 with @xmath82 , this construction defines a riemann surface @xmath7 with a flat structure . the local @xmath12 s glue together to a quadratic differential @xmath9 , which is holomorphic except for simple poles at vertices where only @xmath83 squares abut .",
    "we can distinguish two cases : if @xmath84 is a square of a one - form @xmath85 the origami is said to be _ oriented _ , otherwise _ non - oriented_. if the origami is oriented , the number of squares abutting at each vertex is divisible by @xmath43 .",
    "this condition is not sufficient , as shown by the following example , where @xmath86 is glued to @xmath87 etc .  along the orientation of the arrow :    [ nonor ]        note however , that if the origami is non - oriented , there is a canonical double covering ( ramified precisely over the points , where @xmath83 squares abutt ) , which is an oriented origami . .",
    "a neccessary and sufficient condition for an origami to be oriented is that the transition functions between the charts consist only of translations . in origami language",
    "this means that upper ( resp .  left ) edges should be glued to lower ( resp .",
    "right ) edges preserving global orientation .",
    "an origami in the above sense defines an unramified covering @xmath88 of a torus punctured at @xmath18 and a ramified covering @xmath89 , also denoted by @xmath90 .",
    "we call this an _ origami covering_.    note that by identifying @xmath81 with @xmath82 we used the elliptic curve with @xmath91 in the first definition .",
    "this choice plays no role in the sequel , because the geodesic curve generated by @xmath6 is independent of this choice .",
    "the fact that origamis indeed define teichmller curves , follows from the result of @xcite , that @xmath64 is commensurable with @xmath92 .",
    "this will also follow from the hurwitz space description in section [ origishur ] .",
    "[ monorem ] we will specify the ( unramified ) covering @xmath90 of degree @xmath93 by its monodromy : fix two generators @xmath94 and @xmath95 of @xmath96 and their images under the monodromy map @xmath97 .",
    "these images determine @xmath90 .",
    "note that simultaneous conjugation in @xmath98 ( i.e.  renumbering the preimages of a basepoint ) gives the same covering .",
    "note also that topologically different coverings may lead to the same origami curve .",
    "the quadratic differential @xmath9 on @xmath7 is obtained using the origami covering as @xmath84 , where @xmath99 and @xmath100 is the unique ( up to scalar multiple ) holomorphic differential on @xmath101 .    in the case of origamis",
    "it is natural to consider the groups @xmath69)$ ] ( or @xmath68 ) , where the marked @xmath20 points are the preimages @xmath102 .",
    "this is for two reasons : first , this finite set of additional marked points replaces @xmath103 by a subgroup of finite index ( see @xcite ) .",
    "note that not any set of additional marked points has this property , see @xcite .",
    "second , the following definitions are best suited with the hurwitz space interpretation in section [ origishur ] and yield that @xmath64 is contained in @xmath92 .",
    "the group @xmath104)}$ ] is called the _ affine group _ of the origami .",
    "the quotient @xmath105 ( or simply @xmath0 ) is called the _ origami curve_. if we consider it as orbifold quotient @xmath106)$ ] it is called the _ orbifold origami curve_.    the map @xmath107 is generically injective and actually injective up to finitely many normal crossings , because it is the image of a geodesic locus under the quotient map of a discrete group .",
    "but the map @xmath108 might be ( see the following example ) a composition of a covering and a generically injective map .",
    "if we want to reestablish injectivity , we will consider the origami curve in @xmath109}$ ] , the moduli space of curves with @xmath20 non - ordered points . to give an example that @xmath110 is a proper subgroup of @xmath64 consider the following thick @xmath111 ( see figure @xmath83 :",

    "one checks that for this origami the matrix @xmath116 is in @xmath74 but neither in @xmath110 nor in @xmath92 .",
    "[ figlmn ]    ]    the affine group also admits the following description ( see also @xcite ) : one can always lift a balanced affine diffeomorphism @xmath117)$ ] to its universal cover @xmath118 .",
    "indeed one can lift an affine diffeomorphism locally to an unramified cover and non - trivial paths provide the obstruction to do this globally .",

    "the following lemma is obvious :    [ normalintermed ] suppose an origami covering factors as @xmath131 .",

    "[ strebelrem ] recall that a holomorphic quadratic differential @xmath9 is called _ strebel _ , if its horizontal trajectories are compact or connect two zeroes of @xmath9 .",
    "a direction @xmath136 for @xmath137 is called strebel for @xmath9 , if @xmath138 is strebel .",
    "a strebel differential decomposes the riemann surface into cylinders swept out by trajectories . with our convention for origamis",
    "( @xmath139 and @xmath9 is made by local @xmath12 ) , the direction @xmath140 is strebel if and only if @xmath141 .",
    "we will tacitly assume this in the sequel .",
    "[ monocylrem]if the origami is given by its monodromy @xmath142 the horizontal trajectories decompose @xmath7 into @xmath143 disjoint unit height cylinders , where @xmath143 is the number of cycles of the permutation @xmath144 .",
    "these cylinders lie in @xmath145 maximal cylinders .",
    "denote by @xmath146 , @xmath147 the core curves of the maximal cylinders .",
    "if both sides of a unit height cylinder contains a zero of @xmath148 , it is of course a maximal cylinder .",
    "consider the family of curves @xmath149 by thm .  3 in @xcite",
    "precisely the hyperbolic lengths of the homotopy classes of @xmath146 tend to zero ( as @xmath150 tends to infinity ) .",
    "hence the family of smooth curves @xmath151 tends for @xmath152 to the stable curve obtained by pinching @xmath146 to nodes .",
    "origami curves were defined in the previous sections as quotients @xmath153 of discs in teichmller space , hence in the analytic category .",
    "but the differential @xmath148 ( or @xmath154 ) was defined by covering data of an elliptic curve ( e.g.  @xmath155 ) .",
    "one expects that the ( orbifold ) origami curve in the analytification of a component of an algebraic hurwitz ( stack resp . )",
    "we prove here that this is indeed the case .",
    "we start with generalities on ( algebraic ) hurwitz stacks . roughly speaking they parametrize isomorphism classes of coverings .",
    "isomorphism here means isomorphism over a _",
    "fixed _ base curve .",
    "notations in this section follow wewers ( @xcite ) .",
    "we only need covers of smooth schemes and we assume all schemes to be schemes over @xmath33 .",
    "let @xmath156 denote the universal family of curves over the smooth stack @xmath157 .",
    "fix a ( `` ramification '' ) divisor @xmath158 .",
    "of course we have elliptic curves , maybe with additional structures in mind . for",
    "any @xmath157-scheme @xmath159 let @xmath160 be the category of finite covers @xmath161 of fixed degree @xmath93 and fixed genus @xmath8 of @xmath7 , ramified over @xmath162 , where @xmath163 .",
    "( maybe the notation @xmath164 would be more precise . ) a morphism from @xmath165 to @xmath166 is a morphism @xmath167 plus a morphims @xmath168 over the induced morphism @xmath169 .",
    "we cite th .",
    "4.1.2 from @xcite :    [ wewprop ] the hurwitz stack @xmath170 is a smooth stack over @xmath33 , tale over @xmath157 .",
    "the stack @xmath170 has a coarse moduli space @xmath171 , which is also defined over @xmath33 .",
    "if we replace in the above definition @xmath157 by @xmath172 we obtain an analytic stack @xmath173 , whose coarse moduli space is @xmath174 . in the sequel",
    "we do not distinguish between @xmath175 and @xmath176 for simplicity of notation .",
    "[ hurprop ] let @xmath175 be the universal family over the moduli stack @xmath177 and @xmath178 the divisor corresponding to the section .",
    "let @xmath179 be the connected component of @xmath170 which contains @xmath180 .",
    "then the orbifold origami curve @xmath181 coincides ( as functor ( analytic spaces ) @xmath182 ( sets ) ) with @xmath183 .",

    "we call this connected component @xmath191 and we let @xmath192 be the corresponding component of @xmath193 ( after forgetting the teichmller marking ) .",
    "@xmath192 stems from a uniquely determined connected component @xmath194 of @xmath170 .",
    "it remains to check that @xmath192 is the quotient stack @xmath195)$ ] .",
    "this easily follows from unwinding definitions , noting that deck transformations respect the set @xmath102 .",
    "@xmath196    origami curves are geometric components of a hurwitz space defined over @xmath33 .",
    "hence they are defined over number fields and there is a natural @xmath2-action on the set of origami curves .",
    "the morphism @xmath197 ( and its orbifold version ) is defined over a number field and there is a natural @xmath2-action on the set of embedded origami curves .    * proof : * for the second claim note that the forgetful functor @xmath198 is defined over @xmath33 .",
    "hence the morphism between the geometric components of the ( coarsely ) representing schemes are defined over finite extensions of @xmath33 .",
    "@xmath196 .",
    "there are obviously substacks of @xmath170 which are defined over @xmath33 , for example the hurwitz spaces with fixed monodromy ( see e.g.  @xcite ) .",
    "each galois invariant additional structure describes a substack defined over @xmath33 .",
    "finding components of @xmath199 that are irreducible over @xmath33 has been studied in the context of dessins denfants under the name of giving a _",
    "complete list of galois invariants_. one can ask the same question for @xmath170 .",
    "here is a list ( certainly not complete ) of galois invariants known to the author .",
    "the given references consider the invariants from quite different viewpoints .",
    "@xmath200 monodromy groups and ramification indices , or more generally the nielsen classes are galois invariant . @xmath200",
    "if the ramification indices of @xmath90 over @xmath18 are all odd , the parity of the spin structure ( see @xcite ) is a galois invariant .",
    "@xmath200 if @xmath201 there is a @xmath83-division point @xmath202 in @xmath101 such that @xmath203 is equivariant with respect to the ( hyper)elliptic involutions on @xmath7 and @xmath101 ( see @xcite ) . the property whether or not @xmath204 is a galois invariant .",
    "in this section we examine two origamis , the smallest origami which is not an elliptic curve and the smallest one that can be used for @xmath17-considerations . in both cases",
    "we explicitely describe the equation of the geodesic curve .",
    "we now study the simplest origami which is not an elliptic curve , i.e. such that @xmath90 is not an isogeny .",
    "it is called @xmath15 in @xcite , see the left half of figure @xmath205 .",
    "the sides are glued naturally , i.e.  @xmath112 with @xmath113 and @xmath115 with @xmath114 .",
    "the affine group of this origami @xmath206 contains the horizontal and vertical translation by @xmath83 , hence the modular group @xmath207 and also @xmath208 in fact @xmath159 corresponds to rotation by @xmath209 . and",
    "if @xmath210 were in @xmath206 one could map @xmath211 to one of the other vertical edges and extend this map to a diffeomorphism , that locally looks like @xmath210 . but this leads to a contradiction in each of the cases .",
    "see @xcite for an algorithm to determine the affine group of an origami .",
    "we conclude that @xmath212 is a degree @xmath205 cover",
    ".    we can illustrate remark [ monorem ] here : fix @xmath101 and @xmath213 .",
    "the coverings with monodromy @xmath214 , @xmath215 ( the @xmath15 ) and with monodromy @xmath216 , @xmath217 are topologically different ( i.e.  one can not obtain one from the other by deck transformations and renumbering of the preimages )",
    ". nevertheless the origami curves coincide .",
    "we can see geometrically , that the corresponding origami covering @xmath218 commutes with the hyperelliptic involutions @xmath219 and @xmath220 on @xmath7 and @xmath101 respectively ( see figure @xmath205 ) .",
    "[ figl22 ]    ]    when giving the equation of this family , we work for simplicity over @xmath221 ( with coordinate @xmath150 ) instead of its quotient by @xmath159 to have all weierstra  points available .",
    "[ eq22prop ] the equation of the family @xmath222 is given by @xmath223 together with the morphism @xmath224 , where @xmath225 .",

    "the origami @xmath16 is of genus @xmath241 and it is the origami of lowest degree , that has a strebel direction with @xmath242 cylinders ( namely e.g.the vertical ones ) .",
    "this means ( see rem .  [ monocylrem ] ) that the origami curve passes through a maximally degenerate point of ( the compactification of ) @xmath243 and will be important in section [ compgalact ] . here _ maximally degenerate _",
    "means that the stable curve consists of a graph of @xmath244 s with three marked points or normal crossings .    for each elliptic curve @xmath101 the covering @xmath180",
    "is ramified at two points of order @xmath83 ( but not galois ) .",
    "it factors as @xmath245 in a degree @xmath83 covering @xmath246 and an isogeny @xmath247 of degree @xmath83 .",

    "* proof : * one notices from figure @xmath43 that @xmath207 is contained in the affine group @xmath110 of @xmath16 and by inspection ( using e.g.  @xcite ) one finds , that it is not bigger . to determine the equations note that the hyperelliptic involution @xmath219 of @xmath7 is compatible with @xmath260 and the elliptic involution @xmath261 and @xmath262 .",
    "the weiersta  points of these curves are as follows :    [ figwpons2 ]        to determine @xmath90 it is sufficient to find maps @xmath263 with the correct behaviour and in fact the polynomials @xmath264 and @xmath265 do the job .",
    "@xmath196    [ orbs2 ] the orbifold structure of @xmath266 consists precisely of a globally acting group @xmath267 given by the hyperelliptic involution and the automorphism @xmath268 .",
    "fix @xmath24 and let @xmath269 its fixed field . we first prove faithfulness in a weak sense :    [ weakfaithful ] for each @xmath24 and each elliptic curve @xmath101 defined over @xmath270 there is a covering @xmath180 , unramified except over one point , such that @xmath271 is not @xmath272-isomorphic to @xmath90 .",
    "* proof : * we will derive this from a corresponding result concerning dessins denfants : as shown in @xcite th .",
    "ii.4 there exists a belyi morphism @xmath273 , i.e.  unramified outside @xmath274 , such that @xmath275 .",
    "we may also suppose that @xmath276 is pure , i.e. that precisely the preimage of @xmath232 consists only of points ramified of order @xmath83 .",
    "let @xmath277 be the double cover ramified over @xmath278 .",
    "we take the pullback of @xmath276 by the morphism @xmath279 and call the desingularisation @xmath280 .",
    "the morphism @xmath281 is ramified at most over @xmath278 and hence after multiplication by @xmath83 the map @xmath282 \\circ \\widetilde{\\pi}$ ] defines an origami .",
    "suppose there is a @xmath272-isomorphism @xmath283 with @xmath284 .",
    "we claim that this implies @xmath285 : as @xmath101 and @xmath286 $ ] are defined over @xmath270 the difference morphism @xmath287 maps to the finite kernel of @xmath286 $ ] .",
    "we can conclude because @xmath288 and hence @xmath289 is distinguished by the purity hypothesis .",
    "let @xmath290 be the involution on @xmath7 induced by the elliptic involution of @xmath101 .",
    "once we have shown that @xmath291 , the isomorphism @xmath292 descends to @xmath244 and gives the desired contradiction . but both @xmath290 and @xmath293 are involutions with the same number of fixed points . since @xmath294 the involutions have to coincide by the uniqueness of the hyperelliptic involution .",
    "@xmath196    looking closer at the proof of th .",
    "ii.4 in @xcite , we can choose the morphism @xmath276 in the above proof such that its ramification over @xmath232 consists only of points of order @xmath83 , that @xmath276 is totally ramified over @xmath18 and that the ramification behaviour over @xmath28 is different from these two .",
    "let @xmath295}$ ] denote the moduli stack of elliptic curves with level @xmath83 structure .",
    "we will use the non - calligraphic letters ( e.g.  @xmath296 } \\cong { \\mathbb{p}}^\\ast$ ] ) for the corresponding coarse moduli spaces .",
    "the orbifold origami curve @xmath297 as constructed in the preceding lemma starting with a belyi morphism @xmath276 , whose ramification behaviour over @xmath28 , @xmath232 and @xmath18 is pairwise distinct , is isomorphic to @xmath295}$ ] , hence @xmath298 .",
    "* proof : * we continue with the construction and the notations from the proof of the above lemma .",
    "first we prove that @xmath295}$ ] surjects onto @xmath297 : for this purpose we need to construct a family over @xmath295}$ ] of coverings of the universal family @xmath299}$ ] .",
    "let @xmath300 be the quotient by the elliptic involution @xmath220 followed by the canonical projection @xmath301 } \\to { \\mathbb{p}}^1 $ ] .",
    "( the quotient @xmath302 is indeed a trivial bundle as it contains @xmath43 disjoint ( weierstra ) sections ) .",
    "take the desingularisation of @xmath303}$ ] , where the morphisms in the fibred product are @xmath276 and @xmath279 respectively .",
    "the singular locus of the fibre product is tale over the base and thus the desingularisation is still a flat family of curves , which we denote by @xmath304}$ ] .",
    "let @xmath305 denote the composition of the second projection with the multiplication by @xmath83 .",
    "we thus constructed a topologically locally trivial family of coverings over @xmath295}$ ] .",
    "this family contains by construction the covering @xmath89 of the preceding lemma ( which we also denoted by @xmath90 ) , hence does the job by prop .",
    "[ hurprop ] .    it remains to exclude that @xmath295 } \\to c^{{{\\rm orb}}}$ ] is a cover of degree greater than one or equivalently that @xmath306 is a cover of degree greater than one .",
    "we have to exclude that the affine group of @xmath90 is bigger than @xmath207 . fix a fibre @xmath307 } \\to e$ ] of @xmath305 and call this covering also @xmath308 \\circ \\tilde{\\pi}$ ] .",
    "the subgroup of @xmath309 corresponding to @xmath286 $ ] is generated by @xmath310 and @xmath311 .",
    "it is obviously characteristic and hence by lemma [ normalintermed ] an affine diffeomorphism @xmath134 over @xmath312 descends to an affine diffeomorphism @xmath313}:e^{[2 ] } \\to e^{[2]}$ ] .",
    "if @xmath314 is not in @xmath207 , the morphism @xmath313}$ ] has to permute the @xmath83-division points of @xmath315}$ ] .",
    "but the fibres of @xmath316 over the @xmath83-division points are different by our hypothesis on @xmath276 : one fibre consists of unramified points that are all fixed by the hyperelliptic involution of @xmath7 .",
    "one consists of unramified points that are pairwise interchanged by the hyperelliptic involution .",
    "one consists of @xmath83 points and the last one has a ramification behaviour different from the above . as an affine diffeomorphism has to preserve the ramification order and fixed points of the hyperelliptic involution , this leads to a contradiction .",

    "dessins denfants _ in : the grothendieck theory of dessins denfants , lms lecture notes 200 ( 1994 ) schneps , l. , _ automorphisms of curves and their role in grothendieck - teichmller theory _ , preprint ( 2004 ) wewers , s. , _ constructing hurwitz spaces _ , dissertation , essen ( 1998 )"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> teichmller curves are geodesic discs in teichmller space that project to algebraic curves @xmath0 in the moduli space @xmath1 . some teichmller curves can be considered as components of hurwitz spaces . </S>",
    "<S> we show that the absolute galois group @xmath2 acts faithfully on the set of these embedded curves . </S>",
    "<S> we also compare the action of @xmath2 on @xmath3 with the one on @xmath4 and obtain a relation in the grothendieck - teichmller group , seemingly independent of the known ones . </S>"
  ]
}
